title.value: Learning graph geometry and topology using dynamical systems based message-passing
title.quote: Learning graph geometry and topology using dynamical systems based message-passing

extractions.description: In this paper, we introduce DYMAG: a message passing paradigm for GNNs built on the expressive power of continuous, multiscale graph-dynamics. DYMAG leverages complex graph dynamics based on the heat and wave equation as well as a more complex equation which admits chaotic solutions to generate multiscale representations linked to various graph topological and spectral properties. The approach achieves superior performance in tasks such as recovering generating parameters of random graphs and predicting features of biomolecules.

type.justification: The paper introduces a novel model and evaluates it through a series of experiments on synthetic and citation network datasets, as well as biomolecular tasks.
type.quote: We next experimentally demonstrate the ability of DYMAG to overcome the limitations of standard GNNs described in point (1) and (2) concerning their inability to capture graph topological properties and multiscale views of graph properties.

name.justification: The primary focus of the research is on enhancing message passing in Graph Neural Networks through the introduction of DYMAG which uses continuous, multiscale graph dynamics.
name.quote: We propose Dynamic Multiscale Aggregation on Graphs (DYMAG) to directly address these two issues.

name.justification: The paper extensively discusses and leverages graph dynamics, particularly focusing on heat and wave equations and chaotic dynamics for better message passing.
name.quote: To address point (1), DYMAG utilizes complex, continuous-time dynamics.

name.justification: The paper relates graph topology, geometry, and spectral properties to the dynamic solutions, falling under the domain of geometric deep learning.
name.quote: The continuous nature of the dynamics is leveraged to generate multiscale (dynamic-time snapshot) representations which we prove are linked to various graph topological and spectral properties.

name.justification: This is the primary model proposed and discussed throughout the paper.
name.quote: We propose Dynamic Multiscale Aggregation on Graphs (DYMAG) to directly address these two issues.

is_contributed.justification: The model is introduced as a novel contribution in the paper.
is_contributed.quote: We propose Dynamic Multiscale Aggregation on Graphs (DYMAG) to directly address these two issues.

is_executed.justification: The model is experimentally evaluated on various datasets as discussed in the paper.
is_executed.quote: We next experimentally demonstrate the ability of DYMAG...

is_compared.justification: The model's performance is compared against various other known models such as GNN, GAT, GIN, etc.
is_compared.quote: We compare against a traditional message passing GNN, Graph Attention Network (GAT) [41], Graph Isomorphism Network (GIN) [43], Graph Neural Diffusion (GRAND) [8], and GRAND++ [39].

referenced_paper_title.justification: DYMAG is the primary new model introduced in this paper.
referenced_paper_title.quote: We propose Dynamic Multiscale Aggregation on Graphs (DYMAG) to directly address these two issues.

name.justification: The Cora dataset is used for performance evaluation in the experiments.
name.quote: We find that DYMAG outperforms other methods at predicting salient features of various biomolecules... including Cora.
